node.title: Running her first marathon, Abby Wambach plans to leave her teammates behind.
node.alt: Abby Wambach was set to run in the 2020 New York City Marathon before it was canceled because of the pandemic.
node.description: The former U.S. women’s soccer star was on the start line of the New York City Marathon with three of her former teammates.
node.content: ["Abby Wambach would really like to be done with running. At least that\u2019s what she said before boarding a plane to run the New York City Marathon on Sunday.", "It\u2019s not like she isn\u2019t used to training: When she retired from the U.S. women\u2019s soccer team in 2015, she had secured 184 goals, two Olympic gold medals and a World Cup championship.", "It\u2019s just that she\u2019s been training for this particular marathon for quite a long time. She began running in earnest in 2018, a progression she described as one from walking to something she calls \u201cwogging\u201d to jogging to running.", "In 2019, she decided to try to fulfill what she called a \u201cweird dream\u201d of becoming a marathoner. So she began training for the 2020 New York City Marathon.", "The cancellation of last year\u2019s race was a relief, she said, until she realized she\u2019s been training for a marathon for several years.", "On Sunday, she will line up at the marathon start line at the base of the Verrazano Bridge with the former U.S. women\u2019s soccer players Leslie Osborne, Lauren Holiday and Kate Markgraf, now the general manager of the U.S. women\u2019s soccer team.", "They\u2019re excited to run together, but Wambach is charging her headphones, just in case.", "\u201cI\u2019m planning on going quicker than I\u2019m thinking I will,\u201d she said a few days before the race. \u201cI\u2019m very competitive.\u201d"]
